p.content: Verbs express actions, states, or emotions. The types of verbal inflection and agreement features carried by verbs are detailed first. The issue of when a subject may be missing is discussed in section
, and auxiliaries are covered in section
. Examples of the verbs used in basic sentences are found in section
. More complex constructions including verbs are covered in sections
Verbs and auxiliaries usually carry inflection features, such as tense, aspect, and/or mood. In most cases, these features are added by affixes, but they may also be part of irregular verb forms.
The following inflection features are marked on verbs and/or auxiliaries in

Verbs and auxiliaries may also carry agreement features that force agreement with the subject, and sometimes also with the direct object. Most of these features are added by affixes or pronominal clitics which may attach to the verb. Animacy of a subject or object is most likely a property of the semantics of the individual verb itself, but it is marked by an affix in some languages.
The following agreement features are marked on verbs and/or auxiliaries in

Some languages are called pro-drop languages because they allow a subject and/or object to be missing or unexpressed in their normal syntactic position. For example, in Spanish the normal way to say “I buy a book” is
rather than with the overt subject pronoun included:
. This is not allowed in English, except for imperatives. (The missing subject of infinitives in embedded complements will be covered in section

Some languages are not really pro-drop languages, but at least some of the pronouns are clitics which can attach to the verb. When this happens, there is no pronoun or nominal phrase in subject position, so the sentence appears the same as in a true pro-drop language.
In

case.caseText: pro-drop is not allowed. The subject must be overt except in imperatives.
pro-drop is not allowed. The subject must be overt even in imperatives.
pro-drop of the subject is allowed in any type of sentence.
the subject may look like it is missing due to pronominal clitics attaching to the verb, but it is not a true pro-drop language.
not
also

There are several kinds of auxiliary elements, including positive and negative varieties, as well as nonfinite, motion and other types. Each type will be covered in turn.
Some languages have positive auxiliary elements that are separate words, and some can have more than one auxiliary element before the main verb. Examples for English transitive sentences include:
p.langData: The boy will hit the ball
The boy might have hit the ball
p.content: and
p.langData: The boy might have been hitting the ball

case.caseText: does not have any
has some

p.content: positive auxiliaries which are written as separate words.

case.caseText: optional
required
only one is possible
more than one may occur

text.content: After an auxiliary, the normal VSO order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is Aux V S O.
may change so the subject appears directly after the auxiliary and before the verb. The order in these clauses is Aux S V O.

text.content: Before an auxiliary, the normal OSV order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is O S V Aux.
may change so the subject appears directly after the verb and before the auxiliary. The order in these clauses is O V S Aux.

p.content: Examples of auxiliaries in
are:
Examples of sentences including these auxiliaries are:
In some languages verbal negation is an auxiliary element, while in others it is simply a verbal affix. English has both the negative auxiliary
, which is a separate word that must always follow another auxiliary, and the contraction form
, which is written as a suffix on the auxiliary. Examples of English negative transitive sentences include:
p.langData: The boy did not hit the ball
The boy didn’t hit the ball
p.content: and
p.langData: The boy might not have hit the ball

case.caseText: has one or more
does not have any

p.content: negative auxiliaries which are written as separate words.

case.caseText: may
may not

text.content: be the only auxiliary in the phrase;

case.caseText: no other
the presence of another

p.content: In

case.caseText: there is also a negative affix which attaches to a positive auxiliary to make it negative,
there is not any negative affix which attaches to a positive auxiliary to make it negative,
and but there is a negative verbal affix.
but not nor any negative verbal affix.

The nonfinite word
used in English embedded clauses also acts as an auxiliary in that it fills the same position and can occur before other auxiliaries. For example,
p.langData: The boy would like to have hit the ball

case.caseText: does not have any
has some

p.content: nonfinite auxiliary-type markers which are written as separate words.

case.caseText: optional
required

text.content: After a nonfinite auxiliary, the normal VSO order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is Aux V S O.
may change so the subject appears directly after the auxiliary and before the verb. The order in these clauses is Aux S V O.

text.content: Before a nonfinite auxiliary, the normal OSV order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is O S V Aux.
may change so the subject appears directly after the verb and before the auxiliary. The order in these clauses is O V S Aux.

is/are:

Some languages have other words that act like auxiliaries, such as motion auxiliaries or loan markers, which share the same subject and complements as the main verb.

case.caseText: does not have any
has some

p.content: auxiliaries of this type which are written as separate words.

text.content: After one of these auxiliaries, the normal VSO order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is Aux V S O.
may change so the subject appears directly after the auxiliary and before the verb. The order in these clauses is Aux S V O.

text.content: Before one of these auxiliaries, the normal OSV order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is O S V Aux.
may change so the subject appears directly after the verb and before the auxiliary. The order in these clauses is O V S Aux.
